intro: Passerina corymbosa, commonly known as the clustered pasqueflower, is a flowering plant native to the mountainous regions of western North America. It is a member of the Ranunculaceae family, characterized by its showy, often colorful flowers. The plant typically grows in alpine and subalpine habitats, where it thrives in well-drained soils and full sun. Its flowers, which bloom in early spring, are usually pink or white and are clustered in corymbs, giving it its scientific name. Passerina corymbosa is known for its ornamental value and is sometimes cultivated in gardens that mimic its natural environment.
